William Pike is a PhD candidate and research assistant at the Department of Geography and GeoVISTA Center, Penn State, University Park, as well as the developer of the Codex and e-Delphi tools discussed in this paper. His research interests include knowledge representation, knowledge-sharing systems, and the role of cyberinfrastructure in the process of scientific discovery and communication. He may be reached at wpike@psu.edu. Brent Yarnal is a professor of geography at and director of Penn State's Center for Integrated Regional Assessment. He was also a contributor to the U.S. National Assessment of Climate Change and the Association of American Geographers Global Change and Local Places project. Yarnal's research focuses on global change in local places, especially the local and regional causes and impacts of climate change. He may be reached at (814) 865-8190 or via e-mail at alibar@eesi.psu.edu. Alan M. MacEachren is a professor at and director of Penn State's Geo VISTA Center. His research interests include geographic visualization, geocollaboration, interfaces to geospatial information technologies, human spatial cognition as it relates to individual and group use of those technologies, and user-centered design. MacEachren is the author or coeditor of four books, including the forthcoming Exploring Geovisualization, and coeditor of several journal special issues. He also contributed to the U.S. National Research Council reports on the discipline of geography and on computer and information science research challenges associated with geospatial information. He may be reached at maceachren@psu. edu. Mark Gahegan is a professor of geography at Penn State and the North American editor of the International Journal of Geographical Information Science. His research interests are geographical semantics and the representation and exchange of meaning, geographical information science, geocomputation, visualization, artificial intelligence, remote sensing, and digital libraries. Gahegan is part of a team of scientists investigating the use of cyberinfrastructure to support the geosciences research community (www.geongrid.org) and also a member of a Irans-Atlantic research effort to develop cyberinfrastructure to support the development and dissemination of e-learning activities related to geographic education. He may be reached at mng1@psu.edu. Chaoqing Yu is a PhD candidate with the Department of Geography at Penn State. His research focuses on integrating intelligent-agent and GIS technologies for representing human-environment interactions, particularly in encoding the existing social regulations, laws, policies, and plans into executable knowledge bases and linking them with spatial databases. His previous research work includes extending the least-cost algorithms to include bridges and tunnels in roadway planning and studying the agroecological factors that affect the products of high-yield wheat on Qinhai-Tibet Plateau. He may be reached at cxy164@psu.edu. The material presented in this paper is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under grants SBE 9978052, SBE 0138961, and SBE 0243772. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the authors and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

Kettinger/p pCenter for Information Management and Technology Research, College of Business Administration, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC 29208, email: bill@sc.edu Varun Grover/p pDepartment of Management Science, College of Business Administration, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC 29208, email: vgrover@darla.badm.sc.edu/p

pSUBO GUHA is a Senior Product Manager at the Integrated Client Server Systems division of NCR Corporation. His current research interests are in business process innovation, TQM and QFD, product planning, and strategic marketing. He has written articles in such journals as MIS Quarterly and Journal of Management Information Systems and several international proceedings./p pVARUN GROVER. See Guest Editors' Introduction./p pWILLIAM J. KETTINGER. See Guest Editors' Introduction./p pJAMES T.C. TENG is Associate Professor of MIS in the Management Science Department of the College of Business Administration at the University of South Carolina. Dr. Teng has held teaching and research positions at several universities, including most recently the University of Pittsburgh. He has written over forty articles on IS subjects and recently has focused his research attention on the business process redesign; he has published on this topic in such journals as California Management Review, Omega, IEEE Transactions in Engineering Management, Journal of Management Information Systems, MIS Quarterly, and Database. He has a Ph.D. in management information systems from the University of Minnesota. In 1992, he received the Outstanding Achievement Award from the Decision Science Institute./p

pWilliam J. Kettinger/p pCenter for Information Management and Technology Research, Department ofManagement Science, College of Business Administration, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC 29208, email: bill@sc.edu/p pChoong C. Lee/p pFranklin P Perdue School of Business, Information & Decision Sciences, Salisbury State University, Salisbury, MD 21801, email. cclee@ssu.edu/p pWilliam J. Kettinger is an associate professor and director of the Center of Information Management and Technology Research at The Darla Moore School of Business at the University of South Carolina. He received his PhD and MS from the University of South Carolina and an MPA from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. His research focuses on strategic management and information-related effectiveness measurement. He is a frequent contributor to such journals as MIS/p pQuarterly, Decision Sciences, JMIS, CA CM, and Long Range Planning. He has coauthored several books and has twice served as a special editor for the Journal of MIS. In 1995, Dr. Kettinger was the recipient of the Society of Information Management's (SIM) best paper award. He currently is serving as a research faculty member on a three-year study sponsored by IMD in Switzerland and Andersen Consulting exploring senior manager's perceptions of corporate effectiveness in the use of information./p pChoong C. Lee is currently an associate professor in the MIS department at Salisbury State University in Salisbury, Maryland. He has a PhD degree from the University of South Carolina and an MBA from the University of Rhode Island. He has been actively involved with related research and consulting projects in the IS service quality measurement and a few other telecommunication issues. Some research results have been published in IS journals, such as Decision Sciences, MIS Quarterly, Information and Management, Journal of Management Information Systems, and others./p

pDonald A. Marchand is a professor of information management and strategy. IMD, Lausanne. Switzerland. William J. Kettinger is director. Center for Information, Management and Technology Research. University of South Carolina School of Business. John D. Rollins is managing partner. Strategic Information Technology Effectiveness Consulting Practice, Anderson Consulting, Philadelphia. Contact the authors at: Marchand@imd.ch. bill@sc.edu and/p pjohn.d.rollins@ac.com./p

pBy: William J. Kettinger/p pMoore School of Business/p pUniversity of South Carolina/p pColumbia, SC 20208/p pU.S.A./p pbill@sc.edu/p pChoong C. Lee/p pGraduate School of Information/p pYonsei University/p pSeoul/p pKOREA/p pcclee@yonsei.ac.kr/p pAbout the Authors/p pWilliam J. Kettinger is an associate professor of Information Systems at the Moore School of Business, University of South Carolina. He teaches and researches in the areas of strategic information management, business process change, and IS performance measurement. He consults domestically and abroad on these topics and has published numerous books and research articles including five previous articles in MIS Quarterly./p pChoong C. Lee is Associate Dean of the Graduate School of Information at Yonsei University, Seoul, Korea. He has a Ph.D. degree in MIS from the University of South Carolina and previously served as an associate professor at Perdue School of Business, Salisbury University. Actively involved with research and consulting projects in IS performance measurement, he also works as a Senior Researcher/Consultant for enterpriseIQ in Lausanne, Switzerland. His past research results have been published in MIS Quarterly, Decision Sciences, Journal of MIS, Communications of the ACM, and Information and Management./p

pBy: William J. Kettinger Center for Information Management/p pand Technology Research Department of Management Science College of Business Administration University of South Carolina Columbia, SC 29208 U.S.A./p pbill@sc.edu/p pChoong C. Lee/p pFranklin P. Perdue School of Business/p pInformation & Decision Sciences Salisbury State University Salisbury, MD 21801 U.S.A./p pcclee@ssu.edu/p pAbout the Authors/p pWilliam J. Kettinger is director of the Center of Information Management and Technology Research at the University of South Carolina. He teaches in the Master's of International Business Studies program and in executive development programs both domestically and aboard. In addition to being on the faculty of USC for many years, Dr. Kettinger has over 18 years professional consulting experience in both the public and private sectors with such organizations as IBM, NCR, Bose, Philips N.V., and the South Carolina state government. Between 1992 and 1994, he assisted AT&T's Software Division in developing a business process management strategy. More recently he has been advising the Business Gateway of the Enterprise Development Institute in building an Internet-based electronic bid matching and EDI capability for small businesses. His current consulting and research focuses on electronic commerce/p pstrategy, business process change, and IS service quality. He has published in such journals as MIS Quarterly, Decision Sciences, Journal of Management Information Systems, Communications of the ACM, Public Administrative Review, Data Base, and Information & Management. He has served as a past special editor for Journal of Management Information Systems and co-edited the book Business Process Change: Concepts, Methods and Technologies. He was a 1995 recipient of the Society for Information Management's Best Paper Award. He received his Ph.D. and an M.S. from the University of South Carolina and an M.P.A. from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst./p pChoong C. Lee is an assistant professor of MIS at the Franklin P. Perdue School of Business at Salisbury State University. He has a Ph.D. in MIS from the University of South Carolina, an MBA from the University of Rhode Island, and a B.A. degree from Yonsei University, Seoul, Korea. Dr. Lee has published in such journals as Decision Sciences, Journal of Management Information Systems, Data Base, Information and Management, and Information Resources Management Journal. His research interests include strategic telecommunication planning, IS service quality, IT impact on strategy and organization structure, IS curriculum design, and IS performance measurement./p

pWanda J. Orlikowski * JoAnne Yates/p pMassachusetts Institute of Technology, Sloan School of Management (E53-325), 50 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142-1347/p pMassachusetts Institute of Technology, Sloan School of Management (E52-544), 50 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142-1347/p pwanda@mit.edu * jyates@mit.edu/p

pKatherine C. Kellogg/p pOrganization Studies, MIT Sloan School of Management, E52-544, 50 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142, kkellogg@mit.edu/p pWanda J. Orlikowski/p pInformation Technology and Organization Studies, MIT Sloan School of Management, E53-325, 50 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142, wanda@mit.edu/p pJoAnne Yates/p pCommunications, Information, and Organization Studies, MIT Sloan School of Management, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142, jyates@mit.edu/p pKatherine C. Kellogg ("Life in the Trading Zone: Structuring Coordination Across Boundaries in Postbureaucratic Organizations") is an assistant professor of organization studies at the MIT Sloan School of Management. Her research explores the micro-mechanisms of institutional change. She examines how professional workers change institutions by altering their day-to-day work practices in response to new demands in their organizational contexts, and how this challenges established forms of expertise, identity, and control. Address: MIT Sloan School, 50 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, MA 02142; e-mail: kkellogg@mit.edu./p pWanda J. Orlikowski ("Life in the Trading Zone: Structuring Coordination Across Boundaries in Postbureaucratic Organizations") is the Eaton-Peabody Chair of Communication Sciences and a professor of information technologies and organization studies at the MIT Sloan School of Management. Her primary research interests focus on the dynamic interaction of organizations and information technology, with particular emphasis on structure, culture, communication, and work practices. She is currently exploring the organizational implications of Internet technologies. Address: MIT Sloan School, 50 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, MA 02142; e-mail: wanda@mit.edu./p pJoAnne Yates ("Life in the Trading Zone: Structuring Coordination Across Boundaries in Postbureaucratic Organizations") is Sloan Distinguished Professor of Management at the MIT Sloan School of Management. She studies how communication and information shape and are shaped by technologies, ideologies, and work practices over time. She also researches communication and work practices around Internet use in contemporary organizations, and around use of earlier technologies historically, as in her recent book Structuring the Information Age: Life Insurance and Technology in the Twentieth Century. Address: MIT Sloan School, 50 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, MA 02142; e-mail: jyates@mit.edu./p

pJoAnne Yates/p pMIT Sloan School of Management/p pWanda Orlikowski/p pMIT Sloan School of Management/p pJoAnne Yates, Sloan Distinguished Professor of Management at MIT's Sloan School of Management, uses both historical and rhetorical methods to study communication systems as they shape and are shaped by technologies, ideologies, and work practices. Her book Control through Communication focuses on communication in American firms from 1850 to 1920. She also collaborates with Wanda Orlikowski on studies of communication practices around electronic media in contemporary organizations. She has published in journals including JBC, Business History Review, Organization Science, Academy of Management Review, and Administrative Science Quarterly, and was the 1990 winner of ABC's Distinguished Researcher Award./p pWanda J. Orlikowski is the Eaton-Peabody Chair of Communication Sciences and a Professor of Information Technologies and Organization Studies at the MIT Sloan School of Management. Her research interests focus on the dynamic interaction of organizations and information technology, with particular emphasis on changes in work, communication, and temporal practices./p pThe authors thank Julie Rennecker for her research assistance on the Mox Corporation project, Paul Cole for facilitating the project, and the Center for Coordination Science at MIT for financial support./p pSend correspondence to JoAnne Yates at Sloan School of Management, MIT E52-- 544, 50 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, MA 02142-1347 or jyates@mit.edu./p

pPeter Weill Massachusetts Institute of Technology/p pMichael Vitale Australian Graduate School of Management/p pAbout the Authors/p pDr. Peter Weill (pweill@mit.edu, web.mit.edu/cisr/www/html/weill.html) is Director of MIT Sloan School's Center for Information Systems Research (CISR) & MIT Senior Research Scientist. He has conducted research and taught programs for MBA and executive education, focusing on the business value of information technology and e-business. Peter has published widely, including award winning books, articles, and case studies./p pDr. Michael Vitale (michaelv@agsm.edu.au) is the Dean and Director of the Australian Graduate School of Management in Sydney. He was formerly a Professor in the Centre for Management of IT at the Melbourne Business School, and the Foundation Professor of Information Systems and Head of the Information Systems Department at the University of Melbourne. Prior to coming to Australia, he was a Fellow at the Ernst & Young Center for Business Innovation in Boston, USA. Dr Vitale was also an Associate Professor of Business Administration at Harvard Business School, where he wrote more than 50 case studies on the use of information technology in organizations. His industry experience includes four years as Vice President of Technology and Corporate Services at the Prudential Insurance Company of America./p

pLORIN M. HITT is an Assistant Professor of Operations and Information Management at The Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania. He received his Ph. D. in management from the MIT Sloan School of Management and his Sc.B. and Sc.M. in engineering from Brown University. His current research is on the role of strategic and organizational factors in the productivity of information systems investments and the economics of contracting for IS outsourcing arrangements. His work has appeared in Management Science, MIS Quarterly, and Economics of Innovation and New Technology./p pERIK BRYNJOLFSSON is an Associate professor at MIT, where he holds the Douglas Drane Chair, and is currently visiting Stanford Business School. His research analyzes the organizational and performance implications of advances in information technology and develops optimal pricing strategies for digital information. His teaching focuses on the strategic uses of IT and electronic commerce. He received A.B. and S.M. degrees from Harvard University and a Ph.D. from MIT. Dr. Brynjolfsson lectures internationally for business and academic audiences. His research has won numerous awards and has frequently been cited in publications such as Fortune, Business Week, The Economist, and Scientific American. Research papers are available from his Web page: http://ccs.mit.edu/erik.html./p
